Please e-mail ADHE Area Coordinator, Dr. Kapil Regmi at kapil.regmi@ubc.ca.

Seminar in Biblical Studies. Title: Disability and Biblical Literature. 
Instructor: Isaac Soon

This course analyzes the portrayal of disability and disabled figures in the Hebrew Bible and the New Testament. The study of disability is a recent advancement in the study of ancient history, especially biblical studies. Students will become familiar with cutting-edge theoretical discussions in the field of disability studies concerning “healing” (or body modification), bodily agency, health, ableism, and normality as they relate to biblical texts. Do these biblical texts portray healing as essential? Is disability an individual or social issue? Do “healthy” lives experience greater quality of living? Do biblical texts hope for a future where disability is eliminated and erased? Are key figures in biblical texts (e.g. Abraham and Sarah, Moses, Jesus, Paul) able-bodied? Focus will be given to representations (vs. realities) of disability, the lived experience of disability in the ancient world, and the recovery of disabled histories. Students will gain skills and knowledge that can be applied to the study of disability in their own respective fields and industries. This course offers students the unique opportunity to challenge contemporary conceptions of disability in the medical sciences, humanities, and popular culture by engaging critically with disability in the past.

If the course is full or blocked, or if you do not meet restrictions for the available seats, please register for the waitlist. Students will be moved manually from the waitlist into the course section in order of registration. If the course is blocked but showing available seats, this is normal and means that waitlist transfer have not yet taken place. Email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with any questions.

Seminar in Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Archaeology. 
Title: Roman Historical Relief Sculpture. This course will examine historical relief sculpture used on imperial monuments. We will look at the development of this type of representation from Republic precedents until late antiquity. Some of the topics that will be examined are the use of narrative, iconography and symbol, the response of the viewer and the reception of these monuments. The purpose and context of these works within the imperial policy of each emperor will also be considered. While the course will concentrate on monuments in the city of Rome, we will also discuss some examples from outside the capital. Students will develop the skills required to evaluate and utilise various source materials, to engage with the scholarship on the topic, and to present their research in oral presentations and written assignments.

If the course is full or blocked, or if you do not meet restrictions for the available seats, please register for the waitlist. Students will be moved manually from the waitlist into the course section in order of registration. If the course is blocked but showing available seats, this is normal and means that waitlist transfer have not yet taken place. Email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with any questions.
Honours Essay. Declared honours students must contact amne.undergrad@ubc.ca to be registered in this course.

This course explores the rich history of anthropology and its theoretical contributions to understanding human behavior. By studying the works of influential scholars across major anthropological traditions, we discuss the discipline's “conditions of existence.” Through contextualizing key theorists and their texts, we explore the central questions driving anthropological inquiry and study the evolution of concepts and theories. Through critical analysis, we navigate the interplay between theoretical frameworks, social contexts, and ongoing scholarly dialogue. This course therefore helps us explore our discipline's intellectual heritage.

Course Section: ANTH_V 404-A_001 - Ethnography in Circumpolar North: Comparative Perspectives. (A)
Course Section Definition Public Notes: This course introduces students to the ethnography of the circumpolar regions of North America, Scandinavia, and Russia. We will consider the factors that define this region and the ways that circumpolar regions are both similar and different. We will critically consider early approaches to classification in the Arctic and subarctic in regard to language, material culture, and social organization, and we will consider how these categories are mirrored in many contemporary Indigenous classifications emerging to define parameters of identity.  We will discuss anthropological models of realities (ontologies), belief systems, cultural ecology, political economy, ritual practice, concepts of ethnicity, and gender systems in terms of how they intersect with contemporary local concerns about power, systems of knowledge and personhood, gender systems, and national identity.

Course Section: ANTH_V 429-001 - Global Health in Cross-Cultural Contexts

Course Section Definition Public Notes: This two-term course explores contemporary museum practices, from collecting and conservation to repatriation and exhibition-making. We will collectively curate an exhibition on Haida manga (the art of Michael Nicoll Yahgulanaas). This course looks at museum practices including collecting, conservation, cataloguing and digitization; repatriation or the return of cultural objects; museum education; exhibition design and exhibition making, with a focus on the Museum of Anthropology. During this year long course, we will be curating an exhibition on Haida manga (the art of Michael Nicoll Yahgulanaas) in the IKB Learning Centre (4 display cases) and in the Department of Anthropology (2 display cases). We will meet with museum professionals, curators, and artists and find out more about their practices. We will learn to write and design exhibition labels and graphic panels; to write an exhibition review; to make a collective artwork; to organize public programs and to publicize our exhibition.

Course Section: APBI_V 460-001 - Agroecology III: Synthesis and evaluation
APBI_V 465-001 - Capstone in Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems

Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Deadline to register is Aug 22 due to processing of field trip insurance. Mandatory field school component from August 27 5PM to August 30 11AM in Sts’ailes, with field camp based in Chehalis River campground. Studying how parent material, climate and land use affect soil-plant interactions and resulting soil profile development is central for understanding the rationale behind soil classification and for applying the basic concepts of land use and management that optimize resiliency and sustainability in terrestrial ecosystems. Knowledge of pedology, soil genesis and soil classification are fundamental to the management of land resources, from both practical and policy perspectives. For students interested in gaining more depth in understanding basic concepts in pedology, soil genesis and applying soil classification principles, APBI 490F is a foundational course. This course will combine in-class (lectures on soil genesis and soil taxonomy principles, together with flipped classroom approaches) and in-field learnings (3-night field school last week of August).

If you meet the requirements for the course/waitlist but are not able to self-register, please fill out this 2024 Winter Session Registration Request for LFS Courses form. An LFS Academic Advisor will assess your eligibility for registration and you will be notified accordingly.
